c74object.name: the.mc.jit.mnemonic~
c74object.digest: Replace a jit.catch~ for non-realtime rendering (W.I.P.)
c74object.description:
Written by Tim Heinze © 2020, www.xenorama.com.
Write signal data to blocks of matrices to later recall them for offline rendering. Replace any jit.catch~ or mc.jit.catch~ object in the patcher by this object. Satisfactory results cannot be guaranteed when working with open end recordings, long audiofiles or variyng output intervals. See the discussion for more info.
c74object.discussion:
the.jit.thalamus providing a central context is required in the enviroment.
Disclaimer: the.mc.jit.mnemonic~ is to be seen as a work-in-progress-solution to support existing jit.catch~ objects in the Jitter environment. Limitations are that the results may not match the intended/expected matrices to 100% accuracy, changes to mode and framesize cannot be applied during recording/performance and triggering output of the internal jit.catch~ is likely to only work when applied at low priority (i.e. using a qmetro).
The basic functionality of this object is built around a jit.concat capturing the resulting matrices in blocks, storing them temporarily to disk to recompile them into a large jxf-format file to be read by a jit.matrixset. A separate dictionary assigns the blocks to their different sizes. The final set of matrices has to have the largest dimension recorded in the process to avoid data loss and wrong interpolation. Upon rebuilding the entire stream, each block is read from in sizes of matrices recorded per frame.
In mode 1 the dimension of the resulting matrix varies according to the current framesize and—unfortunately—the interval at which the internal jit.catch~ it being triggered. Hence, when working with low framesize and longer output intervals (these have to be deferred to the low priority thread to avoid Max crashing!), dim[1] can increase heavily to host all data previosuly buffered. This in return may cause the internal jit.concat to fail in recording the output matrix properly.
The unintuitive concapture attribute specifies how many matrices (of whichever size according to mode) will be concatenated into a temproary file, i.e. the lower the value concapture is set to, the more files are being created. While this will increase the efficiency overall, it may yield the odd frame loss during recording—in this case, a higher value may be more efficient. The default value is 66 matrices. This object is subject to further developments, likewise not cleaned up and the helpfile is improvised. Any suggestions welcome.

objarg.name: render-context
objarg.digest: Specify a named render context to bind to.
objarg.description: For convenience, this can be identical to one's world render context name but is to be considered independent. the.jit.thalamus with a unique context name is required running in parallel for all members of the offline render family to sync and respond to.

objarg.name: channels
objarg.description: Number of expected audio channels in the multichannel-signal, likely to represent individual planes of the resulting matrix. Set this argument to '1' when working with single channel audio.

attribute.name: verbose
attribute.description:
When enabled will output a temporary jit_matrix representing an abstract compression of the running multich-channel audio upon completion of a single dimension-scan.
When disabled, a bang in leftmost inlet triggers output of most recent jit_matrix
The default is 0 (disabled)

attribute.name: exportname
attribute.digest: Specify a unique name to write to.
attribute.description:
Specify a unique name to export to after completion of the capturing process, managed by the.jit.thalamus. The resulting filetype is jxf (Jitter binary data file) and can be re-exported/imported using the export and import messages, respectively.
Same as name

attribute.name: name
attribute.digest: Specify a unique name to write to.
attribute.description:
Specify a unique name to export to after completion of the capturing process, managed by the.jit.thalamus. The resulting filetype is jxf (Jitter binary data file) and can be re-exported/imported using the export and import messages, respectively.
Same as exportname

attribute.name: active
attribute.description:
Set the active flag. There are 4 active states available suitable for different purposes:
0 = bypass this object and poke signal data without recording
1 = operate normally (default); poke and record
2 = poke but do not record any new data
3 = (idle)
4 = record but never poke directly to matrix
5 = mute all activity
Note that while recording is disabled, the automatic export upon recording completion (if an exportname is specified) is also disabled and previous files will not be overwritten.
Furthermore, the active flag is overriden by the solo state of the object

attribute.name: downsample
attribute.description: A downsampling factor (default=1). If downsampling value is set to n, each group of n successive samples are averaged.

attribute.name: framesize
attribute.description: In some modes, the width of the output matrix. (default=320)

attribute.name: mode
attribute.description: Four different modes are possible: in mode 0, all data since the last output would be output in a one-dimensional matrix. In mode 1 the amount of buffered data that fits into a multiple of the framesize is output in two dimensions; data not output will be saved for the next time. In these first two modes, every sample collected should be output once and only once. In mode 2 a framesize of the most recent data is output. Mode 3 causes jit.catch~ to behave like an oscilloscope, triggering on channel trigchan when the signal crosses triglevel in the direction trigdir. If the threshold has not been passed for the duration of the entire internal data buffer (100 ms), jit.catch~ reverts temporarily to mode 2 behavior and outputs the most recent data until the threshold is crossed again.

attribute.name: trigdir
attribute.description: The direction to use to identify crosses in the trigger point: 0 is upwards, and 1 is downwards. (default=0)

attribute.name: trigchan
attribute.digest: Set the channel for trigger points
attribute.description: In mode 3, the channel to use for trigger points (default=0)

attribute.name: trigthresh
attribute.description: The signal level at which to trigger a redraw in mode 3 (default=0.0)

attribute.name: concapture
attribute.digest: Specify how many matrices one block is comprised of
attribute.description:
Specify how many matrices one block is comprised of. The default is 66 (matrices) and when this number is reached, a temporary Jitter binary file is created to later form one block in the entire chain of blocks which are being rebuilt using a jit.matrixset. Lower values craete more files and can thus cause the odd frame loss while being more efficient overall. Higher values are prone to lost frames but create less files and hubs between them. When not comfortable with changing this attribute, do leave it at 66. When the results are full of frame drops, do consider increasing or decreasing this value before recording.
See the discussion for more info.

method.name: bang
method.description: Output the latest MSP frame during playback and recording. Essentially the same as sending a bang to jit.catch~.

method.name: multichannelsignal
method.digest: Realtime audio to write to the matrix
method.description: Realtime multichannel-signal to capture within the framesize specified.

method.name: export
method.digest: Export as Jitter binary data file
method.description:
If an exportname has previously been specified, the jxf-file will be written to the dir as specified by the.jit.thalamus.
If an optional argument is provided (symbol), a jxf-file with this name will be written to disk.
The resulting file is designed to populate a jit.matrixset which in return is being read from during offline rendering of complex matrix data.
An additional json-file is also written, holding information about the blocks of recorded data.

method.name: import
method.description:
If an exportname has previously been specified, the jxf-file will be read from the dir as specified by the.jit.thalamus.
If an optional argument is provided (symbol), it will be attempted to read a jxf-file with this name from disk.

method.name: solo
method.description:
According to the numeric argument, will toggle the object's recording/rendering behaviour in relation to other objects in the context
0 = use current active flag if no other object is running @solo 1 or @solo 2, otherwise will set the object to active 0 (bypass)
1 = toggle active operation mode to 1 (operate) along with other objects @solo 1, but not if any object is running @solo 2, in which case it will be muted
2 = unique operation, operate only this object. This will set all other objects' active flag to 5 (mute)

method.name: unsolo
method.digest: Remove all solo states in sibling objects
method.description: The message unsolo does not remove the solo state of this object alone—as would the message solo 0—but does so for all other objects in the context as well.

method.name: getstate
method.digest: Query information about this object's current state
method.description: The message getstate will post relevant status information about this object to the Max Console and open the latter for viewing. Sending this message to the.jit.thalamus will do so for all objects in the current context. Send this message to monitor whether objects will record or render and whether a meaningful name has been allocated to them.
